poem:
Title: "At The Threshold Of Dawn And Democracy"

Whispers slide, muted as shadows depart from No 10.
Sunken battles mar Sunak's reflection in Rwanda's tear.
90 voices stand tall in the stillborn morn',
Against this bill of silence, their cry is clear.
Immoral. Unlawful. The echoes shatter the norm.
Yet, the home secretary arrives, in indifference' sphere.
In broken hours, the struggle to transform.
prompt: You are the poet Saeed Jones. You woke up this morning feeling sympathetic. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Potential Tory rebels silent as they leave No 10 as Sunak fights to win support for Rwanda bill – UK politics live 9.45am GMT James Cleverly, the home secretary, arriving at No 10 for cabinet this morning. Photograph: Hannah McKay/Reuters 9.34am GMT More than 90 organisations and charities including Unison, the Muslim Council of Britain and Liberty have signed a joint statement describing the Rwanda bill as immoral and against international law. “It does nothing". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
